PM11:08am

At the moment we have more ducklings than digits on the VIX with the most noteworthy feature of the last 24 hours being its further collapse, closing down -7.57% last night to 9.77, the lowest close since December 1993. It last closed below 10 in November 2006 and of the 6889 trading days since data was first recorded in 1990, last night’s close was the 4th lowest one. The years that there has been a below 10 close are 2007 (1 day), 2006 (3 days), 1994 (1 day) and 1993 (4 days). On a similar note the S&P 500’s 30-day implied volatility tumbled below 7.5% to close at 7.22% last night, the lowest ever.
It was a similar story for volatility in Europe too yesterday. With the event risk of Sunday’s French election passing with no surprises, the VSTOXX tumbled 15% yesterday to close at 14.39. That’s near the bottom of the YTD range with the low mark set back on March 17th at 11.16 (the average in 2017 so far has been 19.98). FX Vol meanwhile, as measured by the CVIX Index, hit the lowest since October 2014.

PM11:09am

As it happens, in Footsie terms, we actually have a bit of volatility this morning

BE11:12am

European stocks are trading at the highest in two years on the back of positive corporate earnings and pro economic growth Macron win in France.

Chinese equities are relatively flat capping the latest series of losses that shed $500bn off local equities amid a state crackdown on financial leverage.
Gold prices are trading lower at $1,225/oz on the back of a rebound in the US$ index from nearly a six month low it hit Friday last week.
Base metals are in the black taking a break in the latest round of losses led by raising interest rates in China and increasing inventories.
Iron ore futures are lower with the benchmark spot 62% Fe trading at $60.15/t following a five day losing streak, according to Metal Bulletin.
Weakness in the bulk commodity prices is attributed to traders trimming their positions amid escalating borrowing costs in the Chinese market.

11:12 am

undefined
BE11:30am

And so ............. Utility price caps?

Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 199.00, down 3.4 (-1.68%), High: 199.23, Low: 192.00, Volume: 23.27m
11:30 am
PM11:30am

Oh yeah

BE11:31am

I mean, we've only talked about them for two and a half years. There must be new ground to cover.

BE11:31am

Here's the FT story on the latest bit of Tory electioneering.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

https://www.ft.com...-bce4-9023f8c0fd2e

BE11:32am

And it's all much as flagged, expected, leaked, whatever.

BE11:32am

As in, Ofgem gets to pick the cap on the SVT

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Which makes the maths easy

BE11:32am

Because we can use the pre-payment tariff cap benchmark as ... well, as a benchmark.

BE11:33am

Sooooooooooooooooooooo, wholesale price (six month rolling) + environmental levy + CPI + network charge (variable) + an approximately 3% margin on top.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Take away the £62.40 PA per dual customer allowance for prepay.

BE11:33am

That equals a cut in the order of 10%. IN THEORY!

BE11:33am

Here are Bernstein's figures.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

BE11:34am

And in terms of raw impact, this'd be brutal.

BE11:34am

The average short-term impact of a tariff cap would be an average of ~£90 saving per Big 6 dual-fuel customer which would cause a loss to the Big Six of ~£1.7 billion (if annualised) and an average saving of £130 to the SVT customers of the larger independents which translates into an impact of £110 million ( if annualised). These numbers are significant and collectively more than the profits both groups made in 20153 from their UK domestic energy retail segment and would be significant onetime hits to the profitability of all involved in the market.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

(Bernstein again.)

BE11:35am

But, importantly, that's all before hedging. And hedging confuses the picture considerably.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:36 am
BE11:36am

So, to minimise the risk of error, the current SVT is effectively hedged off the forward price a year or two out. And all the companies hedge different levels at different times using different formula, which is what creates a fairly wide spread of pricing in the market.

BE11:37am

A cap ends that.

BE11:37am

A cap will make hedging policies much easier. All you have to do is match the benchmark.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Meaning the big six can adopt the same hedging policy and form into a wee cartel that ekes out the permitted 3% margin.

BE11:37am

Another thing to note is that the independent suppliers have a market share of about 16%, from zero five years ago.

BE11:38am

They've done this by offering fixed price deals that are based on the current wholesale price, unlike the big six and their hedge-forward pricing.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

(and, mostly, the independents have taken a bath as a result ...

BE11:38am

(Independents posted a combined 2015 loss of £26m, excluding Utility Warehouse since it doesn't break out the figures, against £970m profit for the big six.

BE11:38am

(You'll also remember GB Energy recently going belly up and blaming its inability to buy forward to properly hedge itself.)

11:38 am
BE11:39am

But independents aren't nearly as cheap as they were.

BE11:39am

They were a good 16% cheaper two years ago but that's down to just 4% now, and needless to say customer growth has slowed as a result.

BE11:39am

Needless to say, an SVT cap is likely to squeeze that price advantage even further.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

The independents know this. They mostly oppose the policy.

BE11:39am

In fact, pretty much everyone does.

BE11:40am

Thanks again to Bernstein for this handy chart.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

BE11:40am

So ,,,, to summarise ....

BE11:40am

A price cap might well be the nail that kills off the independents and creates a hegemony among the big six.

11:41 am
PM11:41am

This is quite fascinating Bryce. I think

BE11:41am

Which means that -- after a year or so of difficulty as they sort their hedging policies out -- they will deliver a lower but more stable profit margin.

BE11:41am

The average customer might get a lower bill, but also competition will be forcibly weakened.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

The state will, in effect, have forced a cartel on the industry.

PM11:41am

Brilliant

BE11:41am

Which rather underlines what a bloody farce privatisation was.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

\o/

PM11:41am

But if it serves the purpose of wiping out the Labour Party, everything's fine

BE11:41am

Yep.

11:41 am
PM11:42am

PM11:42am

BE11:49am

11:50 am

BE11:50am

PM11:51am

11:51 am
PM11:51am

Really, really short sighted

PM11:51am

All the euro regulators have to do here is copy what the CFTC has imposed

PM11:52am

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Yeah, Germany's gone milder than the FCA and Cyprus.

BE11:52am

Here's Liberum.

BE11:52am

Plus500 (BUY, TP 505p) already operates on this basis so there should be no impact on its business. IG Group (U/R) is likely to be more exposed, albeit the impact we would estimate at very low single-digits in terms of potential revenue loss given Germany accounts for c.5% of group revenue and active clients. We await the findings of the FCA's review, who have suggested leverage limits, potentially the most damaging amendment to regulations.

11:52 am
Plus500 Ltd (PLUS:LSE): Last: 494.06, up 0.8061 (+0.16%), High: 495.00, Low: 492.00, Volume: 87.23k
IG Group Holdings PLC (IGG:LSE): Last: 550.35, down 2.65 (-0.48%), High: 556.50, Low: 546.50, Volume: 940.59k
BE11:53am

... though on IG, we also have Numis turning cautious.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

For the reasons we intro'd with.

BE11:54am

With the VIX trading below ten, a multi decade low and with volatility having been low for some time we are modestly reducing our forecasts for this year. Our Q4 revenue forecast falls by 7% (£9.2m) to £122.3m from £131.5m and our full year pre-tax profit forecast falls 2% to £203m from £208m as we expect marketing and variable staff costs to be lower as a consequence of lower revenues. We believe we have taken a cautious approach, having assumed that the current low market volatility continues all the way to the May period end. We believe IG continues to gain market share and is a long-term winner in the CFD market place. Low volatility for IG is the equivalent of lower markets for fund managers. Separately, BarFin have announced the end of their consultation period and that their initial proposal (no negative balances) will be enacted without further change. IG already has a compliant product set

BE11:54am

A long-term winner: As the CFD industry matures and regulation is introduced to restrict the activities of the less scrupulous providers, we believe IG's market position should improve. We see this enhancing the quality of the group's income and believe its best in class practice will ensure that it is less negatively impacted from regulatory change. We expect the number of providers to shrink as many of IG's smaller competitors are already struggling to break even.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

There's been some speculation around in recent weeks about IG making sense as a Playtech target, incidentally.

BE11:55am

I stress, speculation. Absolutely no idea if there's anything in it.

Playtech PLC (PTEC:LSE): Last: 959.50, up 17 (+1.80%), High: 960.00, Low: 945.50, Volume: 342.79k

BE11:57am

11:57 am
undefined
PM11:58am

What to wrap up on ...?

BE11:58am

Good question. Fantasy M&A?

11:58 am
PM11:58am

Why not

BE11:59am

Citi shoving Spirent.

BE11:59am

We believe that following the Ixia’s merger with Keystone, markets could view Spirent as a potential takeover target given its quality business and favorable exposure to end markets. We see +32% upside if we value Spirent FY17e base case estimates (11.5% margin) on testing companies acquired multiples and +76% upside on recovery margins (15.7%).

11:59 am
Spirent Communications plc (SPT:LSE): Last: 119.25, up 2.75 (+2.36%), High: 122.50, Low: 118.50, Volume: 805.73k
BE11:59am

Whist current multiples are at a premium to history, we believe this premium is justified given the optionality for strong rebound in earnings. The risk-reward for Spirent is more favorable with +76% upside to our recovery case and a downside risk of -19%. We increase our TP to 145p (from 90p) after we revise our earnings estimates, update our WACC to reflect lower equity risk premium, and incorporate a modest 10% M&A premium.
